customData.content: 32-year-old female presented with weakness in her right upper arm lasting for two weeks. Physical examination was unremarkable, other than grade 3 weakness in her right upper limb.

HPI.summary: 32-year-old female presented with weakness in her right upper arm lasting for two weeks.

physical_exam.finding: grade 3 weakness in her right upper limb

customData.content: Patient was hospitalized due to acute venous thromboembolism of the right arm and started on anti-coagulants. Computed tomography (CT) scans of the chest, abdomen and pelvis and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain were performed.

Multiple nodules detected suggestive of extensive metastasis. 1.9 cm left lung mass consistent with lung primary origin. Liver biopsy revealed poorly differentiated LUAD. Core biopsy of left chest wall nodule also revealed poorly differentiated LUAD with tumor cells positive for pan-keratin and TTF-1 and negative for ER, PR, CDX2, WT1, PAX-8, synaptophysin and chromogranin.

imaging.finding: Multiple nodules detected suggestive of extensive metastasis

customData.content: Patient underwent palliative radiation therapy for C5-C7 spine metastases (10 fractions of 300 cGy each) and one dose of chemotherapy with carboplatin and paclitaxel while awaiting molecular profiling results.

Patient expired 13 days following her sole dose of chemotherapy due to disseminated metastatic lung adenocarcinoma and cancer-associated complications including severe respiratory, cardiovascular and renal failure caused by Trousseau syndrome and embolic stroke despite continuing hydrocortisone combined with antibiotic therapy for the last two days preceding her death. Primary cancer was left lung late-stage lung adenocarcinoma (LUAD) with more than 20 synchronous metastases.

diagnoses.label: Secondary malignant neoplasm of unspecified site
Other specified vascular syndromes of brain in cerebrovascular diseases

customData.content: Tumor contents and major/minor copy number changes were estimated by Sequenza (v2.1.2). Somatic single nucleotide variants (SNVs) was first called using MuTect version 1.1.4, VarScan 2 and Strelka2 with default setting, respectively. Nonsynonymous mutations were identified from WES profiling and the binding affinities with patient-restricted MHC Class I molecules of all possible 9- and 10-mer peptides spanning the nonsynonymous mutations were evaluated with the NetMHC3.4 algorithm based on HLA-A, HLA-B, and HLA-C alleles of each patient.
Two sets of PCRs were performed.

data.content: Patient's right arm weakness progressed, leading to hospitalization and diagnosis of acute venous thromboembolism. Anti-coagulation therapy was initiated. CT scans of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis, along with MRI of the brain, were performed to investigate the cause of the weakness and thromboembolism.
Imaging revealed multiple nodules suggestive of extensive metastasis and a 1.9 cm left lung mass. Liver and chest wall biopsies were performed, revealing poorly differentiated LUAD.
Patient received palliative radiation therapy for spine metastases and started on carboplatin and paclitaxel chemotherapy while awaiting molecular profiling results.

Patient expired 13 days after chemotherapy due to disseminated metastatic lung adenocarcinoma and cancer-associated complications, including respiratory, cardiovascular, and renal failure caused by Trousseau syndrome and embolic stroke, despite hydrocortisone and antibiotic therapy.

Tumor contents and major/minor copy number changes were estimated by Sequenza (v2.1.2). Somatic single nucleotide variants (SNVs) was first called using MuTect version 1.1.4, VarScan 2 and Strelka2 with default setting, respectively. Nonsynonymous mutations were identified from WES profiling and the binding affinities with patient-restricted MHC Class I molecules of all possible 9- and 10-mer peptides spanning the nonsynonymous mutations were evaluated with the NetMHC3.4 algorithm based on HLA-A, HLA-B, and HLA-C alleles of each patient.
Two sets of PCRs were performed.
